title: Digitalization and Security in Maritime Logistics
headline: Study cargo documentation types, digitalization and security in this free online course on maritime logistics.
description: This free online course on digitalization and security in maritime logistics teaches you about the importance of correct cargo documentation for import and export. You will learn about the use of electronic data interchange (EDI), as well as the operation of extensible markup language (XML) in shipping manifests, invoices, remittances and bills of lading. Threats and security around maritime transportation are also covered.
courseDescription:
Digitalization and Security in Maritime Logistics is a free online course that begins by introducing you to the importance of accurate cargo documentation, as well as the different details of export and import arrangements. It will also familiarize you with the different types of documents to be used, as well as the agencies mandated by the International Maritime Organization (IMO), which is responsible for the safety and security of shipping around the world. The application of ICT (information communication systems) in supply chain management, as well as the importance of information management, will also be covered in this course.

The material then explains facets of electronic data interchange (EDI), as well as the operations of extensible Markup Language (XML). You will learn how digitalization influences maritime logistics, as well as how technologies are applicable to supply chain management. This course will teach you about how the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT or the interconnected sensors, instruments and other devices that are networked together with computers' industrial applications) helps to optimize the supply chain and the application of big data analytics.

Furthermore, this course will help you get familiar with the historical perspective on the importance of maritime security, as well as the threats to the maritime transportation industry. You will learn about the interaction of a vessel with other modes of transport and the relevance of the ISPS Code (International Ship and Port Facility Security Code). This free online course will be of great interest to anyone wanting to learn more about digitalization and security in the maritime industry.

Start Course Now

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain the importance of cargo documentation. 
    • Discuss the concepts of export and import cargo documentation. 
    • Analyze the commercial and legal need for cargo documentation. 
    • Identify the different types of documents.
    • Outline the agencies mandated by the IMO.
  • Export Cargo Documentation
  • Cargo documentation is commercially as well as legally required to comply with regulations, to identify ownership, to identify responsibility, to process payments, and for the cargo to move from its point of origin to the point of its destination. A large part of these are being captured electronically, using computer based software systems; however, the paper trail is still very visible in less advanced ports where the application of ICT is limited.

    Documentation is essential for the transportation of cargo from the origin to its destination. The shipper includes a full description of the cargo unit in his bill of sale to the consignee, describing the number of pieces and their details. This includes a description of the package with its dimensions, weight, country of origin, center of gravity, and lifting and securing points clearly marked on the outside of the crate. The crate is uniquely identified by a mark or number including the consignee’s name and address and port of discharge. This information is transcribed on to a pro-forma Bill of Lading or a booking note as a means of transmitting these details to the ship’s agent.

    The ship’s agent incorporates the shipper’s data onto the ocean carrier’s official Bill of Lading and the data is entered with the growing list of cargo details on the cargo manifest. The ship’s agent prepares a cargo list for distribution to the stevedores, the port Captain, and the terminal operators with a brief description of the crate and its contents. Extraordinary dimensions of size, weight and hazardous nature of the cargo are also mentioned. A mate’s receipt is prepared with this cargo description. This document is sent to the stevedores for confirmation of receipt of cargo and its condition. Any handling damage is noted at this time. It is then given to the ship’s Chief Officer who signs it and returns it to the ship’s agent.

  • Document Types
  • Documentation associated with a vessel’s arrival, its acceptance of cargo for export, and its departure can be generally classified into two categories. One set of documents is provided by the Ship’s Master to the Port State Control agency and refer to the ship’s operation.

    The Port State Control agency has the authority to determine whether the ship is properly registered, has clean oil discharge records, and is in compliance with security regulations. Officials have the authority to examine every aspect of the ship operation and the prevailing condition of the ship upon its arrival into the port. When any anomalies are detected, officials may prohibit cargo operations until any perceived discrepancies are fixed. Similarly, the ship could be held up from departing until the officials are satisfied that the ship is in compliance with the local and international rules governing the safety of ocean shipping.

    Official agencies empowered by the Port State Control mandates drawn from the International Maritime Organization (IMO) regulations include:
    • The coast guard
    • The port health and sanitation department
    • The customs and excise agency
    • Police
    • Immigration

Officials have the authority to examine every aspect of the ship operation and the prevailing condition of the ship upon its arrival into the port. When any anomalies are detected, officials may prohibit cargo operations until any perceived discrepancies are fixed. Similarly, the ship could be held up from departing until the officials are satisfied that the ship is in compliance with the local and international rules governing the safety of ocean shipping.

    Official agencies empowered by the Port State Control mandates drawn from the International Maritime Organization (IMO) regulations include:
    • The coast guard
    • The port health and sanitation department
    • The customs and excise agency
    • Police
    • Immigration

  • Lesson Summary
    • Cargo documentation is commercially as well as legally required to comply with regulations, to identify ownership, to identify responsibility, to process payments, and for the cargo to move from its point of origin to the point of its destination.
    • Documentation is essential for the transportation of cargo from the origin to its destination. 
    • The shipper includes a full description of the cargo unit in his bill of sale to the consignee, describing the number of pieces and their details. 
    • Documentation is required for the import clearance of cargo at the destination. A systematic procedure and relevant documentation assists in the inward clearance of the cargo consignment.
    • Cargo documentation is commercially as well as legally required to comply with regulations, to identify ownership, to identify responsibility, to process payments, and for the cargo to move from its point of origin to the point of its destination.
    • The Bill of Lading is a legal document internationally accepted as the document of the ownership of the cargo. It is commercially and legally the most important cargo document. 
    • The Port State Control agency has the authority to determine whether the ship is properly registered, has clean oil discharge records, and is in compliance with security regulations.
    • Official agencies empowered by the Port State Control mandate drawn from the International Maritime Organization (IMO) regulations include:
      - The coast guard
      - The port health and sanitation department
      - The customs and excise agency
      - Police
      - Immigration
  • Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain the application of ICT in supply chain management. 
    • Discuss the importance of information management.
    • Outline the distinct facets of Electronic data interchange (EDI).
    • Discuss the operations of the Extensible Markup Language (XML).
    • Explain the role of digitalization in shipping. 
    • Identify the digital trends that will transform container shipping. 
  • Introduction
  • What are the top priorities for logistics and how do you tackle them? Today, every business is a digital business and the impact of digital strategies on supply chain management are of particular importance. For businesses around the globe, their future will be shaped by the success rate of digital transformation efforts.

    Many companies have realized that going digital is the only solution to break traditional supply management chains and move boldly into the future. Digital technology will create a significant improvement in business outcomes, as long as businesses reinvent their supply chain strategies. According to a McKinsey report, only about 40 percent of businesses were digitized in 2016. New industry dynamics are driving supply chains to new levels, with digital transformations occurring across manufacturing sectors and into supply chains at every level. While it will take time for companies to become “fully digitized,” many sectors have passed the halfway point in their transformations. Now is the time to digitize or die.

    The adoption of SCM concept had increasingly forced manufacturer and distributors to focus on their core business and, at the same time, to outsource their transport and logistics activities. Manufacturers and retailers are demanding that all supply chain participants do more integration of their business processes through ICT and Internet technologies. Under this strong pressure, 3PLs are devoting increasing importance to ICT in the management of their businesses.

  • Digitalization in the Marine Industry
  • The Marine industry faces substantial pressure: global trade has decelerated and commodity prices have declined, just as a prolonged shipbuilding cycle resulted in significant overcapacity. The struggle for market share, due to competition and consolidation, necessitates the need for greater efficiency in shipping. Marine offshore is also under pressure, as the decline in oil prices has changed the economics of the oil and gas industry. At the same time, large number of experienced workers are set to retire in the next 5-10 years, posing the risk of a shortage of critical skills.

    Shipping has come under scrutiny by regulatory and environmental bodies for its environmental and safety record. Speculation in shipbuilding and slow economic growth have put the industry under significant economic pressure. The maritime industry needs to become more modern, efficient, and safe. In fact, we are witnessing how this industry is turning from being one of the most conservative industries to being open for new ways of operating.

    Improved satellite connectivity at sea allows the introduction of modern software and cloud computing. Life at sea as we know it, is going to change profoundly. And so will the life at the office. Digitalization will affect almost everything in Shipping due to Improved connectivity, Availability of information to all the stakeholders resulting in Transparency and Team work.

    Informed Planning, operational tasks, and decision-making will be done by more people Creation of virtual teams whose members will be on board / on shore in different places.

The struggle for market share, due to competition and consolidation, necessitates the need for greater efficiency in shipping. Marine offshore is also under pressure, as the decline in oil prices has changed the economics of the oil and gas industry. At the same time, large number of experienced workers are set to retire in the next 5-10 years, posing the risk of a shortage of critical skills.

    Shipping has come under scrutiny by regulatory and environmental bodies for its environmental and safety record. Speculation in shipbuilding and slow economic growth have put the industry under significant economic pressure. The maritime industry needs to become more modern, efficient, and safe. In fact, we are witnessing how this industry is turning from being one of the most conservative industries to being open for new ways of operating.

    Improved satellite connectivity at sea allows the introduction of modern software and cloud computing. Life at sea as we know it, is going to change profoundly. And so will the life at the office. Digitalization will affect almost everything in Shipping due to Improved connectivity, Availability of information to all the stakeholders resulting in Transparency and Team work.

    Informed Planning, operational tasks, and decision-making will be done by more people Creation of virtual teams whose members will be on board / on shore in different places.

  • Cloud Computing
  • “The Cloud” has revolutionized the approach to enterprise IT in almost every industry. It provides the ability to harness essentially unlimited on-demand resources and services in a cost-effective, easy-to-manage and dynamically scalable way. There are two models that are most commonly used to consume cloud-based services.
    • Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS)
      IaaS involves the provision of base infrastructure, primarily computational power and data storage. It enables organisations to “rent” IT capability as required, either instead of or in addition to, owning and maintaining an on-premises data center.
    • Software-as-a-Service (SaaS)
      SaaS is the provision of a complete encapsulated application or service, typically licensed per number of users. The SaaS provider hosts the software in a secure private cloud, allowing multiple users and entities secure access via a web browser to deliver a uniform experience across the board.

  • Sensors for Data Collection
  • Sensor selection for any operation is primarily based on reliability and the cost of the sensing elements and sensors packaging--other than the operational factors discussed below. The technology in selecting the sensing element, and digitization to support the increasingly promoted IoT (Internet of Things) revolution. Though the application of sensors and data derived from, is very vast, only one of the complex example is discussed below, to introduce some important properties to you.

    Considering a medium/high-speed engine running at 1200 rpm, the exhaust temperature can change up and down, from 760* C to 800 °C to 840 °C and in reverse, 10 times per second. Any temperature sensor located at the cylinder head gas outlet will “feel” this ultra-fast peak to peak variation. However, the thermal inertia of the sensor itself is such that the sensitive element inside does not register this variation, as it monitors some kind of intermediate value between peak values.

    The intermediate temperature observed by the hot temperature sensor, very much depends on:
    • The location of the sensor on the exhaust pipe outlet
    • The length of the sensor plunger, in comparison to the exhaust pipe diameter
    • The sensor material, and corresponding thermal coefficients
    • The detailed design of the sensor
  • Thus, by using two different sensor designs, on the same engine, with the same cylinder head, and the same location on the pipe, there will be very little chance of measuring the same “intermediate temperature”

    The intermediate temperature observed by the hot temperature sensor, very much depends on:
    • The location of the sensor on the exhaust pipe outlet
    • The length of the sensor plunger, in comparison to the exhaust pipe diameter
    • The sensor material, and corresponding thermal coefficients
    • The detailed design of the sensor
  • Thus, by using two different sensor designs, on the same engine, with the same cylinder head, and the same location on the pipe, there will be very little chance of measuring the same “intermediate temperature”

  • Lesson Summary
    • Many companies have realized that going digital is the only solution to break traditional supply management chains and move boldly into the future. Digital technology will create a significant improvement in business outcomes, as long as businesses reinvent their supply chain strategies.
    • Maritime logistics is where it is today only because of the capabilities of the current information technology sector. The increasing power of the microchip has made it possible to communicate business information as well as keep track of the millions of pieces of equipment and cargo-carrying containers in the business. 
    • Electronic data interchange (EDI) is an essential part of E-commerce. EDI can be a great deal of help to small and mid-sized businesses that are seeking to automate their order processing and invoicing systems.
    • There are four distinct facets of EDI: volume, diversity, breadth, and depth that, when aggregated, underscores the EDI usage and the expected EDI benefits.
    • EDI systems were introduced to cut costs, errors and wastage involved in paper-based business documents. 
    • XML/EDI is a web specification that allows users greater freedom in sending information and data that are dynamic across the Web.
    • XML defines a standard for encoding the presentation characteristics, structure, and behaviours of data that supports business transactions. 
    • EDI uses unique segment identifiers like tokens to separate and identify data items within messages. XML replaces those same segments with Web tokens which allow XML to express EDI and carry EDI via Web delivery methods.
    • Digitalization will allow the industry to set a new digital framework of how information can or should be exchanged between different counter parties in the future. 
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to: 
    • Explain how digitalization influences maritime logistics. 
    • Discuss how technologies are applicable to supply chain management.
    • Outline how IIOT helps to optimize the supply chain. 
    • Discuss the application of big data analytics. 
    • Outline the processes for the analysis of potential data.
    • Explain how to carry out automatic equipment identification.
  • Introduction
  • The global seaports are of pivotal importance for the world economy. Since 1990, global container traffic has grown by an average of 10% annually. Equally, the steady growth of ship sizes poses major logistical and technical problems worldwide. Given these facts, shipping and maritime logistics would largely benefit from Big Data as well as the emerging digital technologies. Apart from the many positive effects of digitalization in maritime logistics with respect to efficiency, safety and energy-saving, there are, however, also risks (e.g. data abuse, cybercrime).

    Today, more than 90% of the world’s goods transport is handled by the sea. While in 2013 some 9.5 billion tons of sea freight have been loaded at seaports around the world, the total capacity of the global container fleet increased to approximately 20.5 million TEU1 in 2015. The steady growth of ship sizes poses major logistical and technical problems worldwide. 

    Maritime logistics is thus one of the key sectors for digital transformation. With its high degree of networking and its large number of interfaces, maritime logistics offers a broad range of applications for digital technologies. Traffic, port logistics, and just-in-time shipping will change as an electronic revolution takes shape with Big Data and the increasing networking of technologies. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) supports the introduction of electronic data exchange from ship to ship/land and from land to ship, to improve the efficiency, safety, and data security of navigation and communication.

    Maritime logistics is thus one of the key sectors for digital transformation. With its high degree of networking and its large number of interfaces, maritime logistics offers a broad range of applications for digital technologies. Traffic, port logistics, and just-in-time shipping will change as an electronic revolution takes shape with Big Data and the increasing networking of technologies. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) supports the introduction of electronic data exchange from ship to ship/land and from land to ship, to improve the efficiency, safety, and data security of navigation and communication.

  • Advanced Analytical Capabilities
  • Advanced analytical capabilities are quite simply a “must-have” for effective modern supply chain management and shipping. They are the cornerstone of successful optimisation strategies in both localised ship operations and across the wider supply chain network. Big data is the name given to the large volume of data – both structured and unstructured. 

    The analysis of this big data is extremely useful as it allows businesses to uncover hidden patterns, unknown correlations, ambiguities, market trends and other useful information. Companies can analyse these data to identify efficiencies such as quicker routes or preferred ports etc, which can result in an extra 5 to 10% increase in performance. In many respects, analytics is a fundamental capability for the further application of many of the other technologies described here. 

    The applications of analytics throughout the supply chain are vast and as such, must be approached with specific objectives in mind. It is crucial to define the strategic business objectives first, then to identify what insights will help drive those objectives, before defining the best analytical models to use and selecting the data sets required. These objectives can (and often should) be part of a larger goal and strategy, but without clear direction, companies will run the risk of “paralysis by analysis”.

    The analysis of this big data is extremely useful as it allows businesses to uncover hidden patterns, unknown correlations, ambiguities, market trends and other useful information. Companies can analyse these data to identify efficiencies such as quicker routes or preferred ports etc, which can result in an extra 5 to 10% increase in performance. In many respects, analytics is a fundamental capability for the further application of many of the other technologies described here. 

    The applications of analytics throughout the supply chain are vast and as such, must be approached with specific objectives in mind. It is crucial to define the strategic business objectives first, then to identify what insights will help drive those objectives, before defining the best analytical models to use and selecting the data sets required. These objectives can (and often should) be part of a larger goal and strategy, but without clear direction, companies will run the risk of “paralysis by analysis”.

  • IoT and IIoT Applications
  • In the digitalisation process, the Internet of Things (IoT) is an area that covers technologies including ubiquitous computing, pervasive computing, wired/wireless sensors, networks, and embedded systems, forming a communicating-actuating network of a large number of things including Radio-Frequency Identification (RFID) tags, mobile phones, sensors, actuators and etc. 

    Industrial IoT (IIoT) has emerged as a sub-area which focuses more in safety-critical applications in industries where defects and failures in such applications would often result in dangerous situations even loss of lives, hence a fail-safe system is enforced. The design approach of IIoT completely differs from that of a domestic IoT application.

    In short, the IoT and IIoT applications, sense, read, communicate and actuate where necessary, following an Industry-standard in an interoperable communication system, which suits well for that application in a wired or wireless circuit. In simple terms, the measuring and actuating components send and receives the data to a computing device, using any one of the acceptable communication standards. In a real-world application, from the engine room of a ship, all pressures, temperatures, levels, flow, rpm etc are continuously measured and the values (data) are communicated, following a standard protocol, to the computing device. The communication standards follow an industry approved format so that the computing device can interpret quickly. Similarly, the use of RFIDs in container ships have produced vast advantages

  • Automatic Equipment Identification
  • The leading container terminals in the world today handle more than 20 million TEUs per year. This amounts to more than 50,000 movements per day! Keeping track of all these movements would be impossible without efficient automatic equipment identification mechanisms. This sub-section provides an introduction to the role of AEI in container systems in particular and maritime logistics in general. Take a look at the graphical illustration given below which explains how an efficient automatic equipment identification mechanism helps to track containers.

  • The leading container terminals in the world today handle more than 20 million TEUs per year. This amounts to more than 50,000 movements per day! Keeping track of all these movements would be impossible without efficient automatic equipment identification mechanisms. This sub-section provides an introduction to the role of AEI in container systems in particular and maritime logistics in general. Take a look at the graphical illustration given below which explains how an efficient automatic equipment identification mechanism helps to track containers.

  • Lesson Summary
    • The optimization of processes in the maritime logistics chain by new technologies and the resulting reduction of costs, the transparency of the sea transport by sensor chip technologies and the autonomous navigation will play a major role in the digitalization process.
    • Digital technologies will ensure shorter waiting times for ships and faster processing at the terminal.
    • Supply chain management is becoming increasingly more complex as logistics operations span across greater distances and extended partner networks, while consumer expectations become increasingly demanding and innovative competitors squeeze profit margins for more established players.
    • “The Cloud” has revolutionised the approach to enterprise IT in almost every industry. It provides the ability to harness essentially unlimited on-demand resources and services in a cost-effective, easy-to-manage and dynamically scalable way.
    • “Industrial Internet of Things”, or IIoT encompasses a network of smart, interconnected objects that can provide real-time visibility and detailed information on the surrounding environment.
    • Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR) technologies have been used in commercial situations with their ability to supplement the visual experience of users. The two technologies differ somewhat in their applications. 
    • The applications of analytics throughout the supply chain are vast and as such, must be approached with specific objectives in mind. It is crucial to define the strategic business objectives first, then to identify what insights will help drive those objectives, before defining the best analytical models to use and selecting the data sets required. 
  • Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain a historical perspective on the importance of maritime security. 
    • Outline the threats to the maritime transportation industry.
    • Analyze the interaction of a vessel with other modes of transport.
    • Discuss the relevance of the ISPS Code.
    • Identify relevant government legislation and regulations.
    • Explain the legal implications by of actions or non-actions by security personnel.

  • Relevant International Conventions, Codes, and Recommendations
  • International conventions are treaties or agreements between states the primary actors in international law. An International Convention is enforced through state law after the State ratifies (agrees) the Convention and enacts it as the law of the state through a bill introduced and then passed in parliament. A code is a set of standards set forth and enforced, through regular checks and certification. A recommendation in relation to security is advice or counsel which although presented as such, the recipient is free to take or leave.

    Previous efforts of IMO toward maritime security, such as MSC/Circ.443, SUA Act, etc. IMO has passed several resolutions to help improve maritime security, and these include
    • IMO Resolution A.545 (13) – measures to prevent acts of piracy and armed robbery against ships (1983)
    • IMO Resolution A.545 (14) – measures to prevent unlawful acts which threaten the safety of ships and the security of their passengers and crews (1985)
    • IMO MSC/Circ.443 – measures to prevent unlawful acts against passengers and crews aboard ships (1986)
    • IMO Suppression of Unlawful Acts Against the Safety of Maritime Navigation (SUA) Convention – for the suppression of unlawful acts against the safety of maritime navigation (in force 1992)
    • IMO MSC/Circ.754 – Passenger ferry security (consideration primarily in respect of passenger ferries operating on international routes and ports serving those routes) (1996)
  • Though there were conventions, circulars and resolutions (as listed above) related to maritime security at sea before September 11, 2001, none of them was mandatory. After the so-called 9/11 incident IMO worked vigorously to improve security at sea.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Multilateral initiatives to combat terrorism at sea are coordinated through the IMO. The outcomes include:
      - IMO Resolution A.924.22 (Nov 2001) - A review and procedure to prevent acts of terrorism which threaten the security of passengers and crew and the safety of ships
      - The International Ship and Port Facility Security Code (ISPS Code) Dec 2002: Created by the Conference of Contracting Governments to the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, and went into effect on July 1, 2004
    • The International Maritime Bureau, a non-profit division of the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) is a key player in suppressing maritime piracy.
    • Piracy and armed attacks continue to occur on an increasingly frequent basis at sea. Armed robbery occurs mostly in port areas, while piracy occurs at sea. 
    • Cargo theft is an age-old problem, that results in a great financial loss to the shipowner. Prevention is the best method to prevent cargo theft.
    • Human trafficking a security threat where human beings can be smuggled through containers. There have been cases of stowaways coming onboard vessels from ports in Africa.
    • Maritime fraud, where seamen employed on board could have a counterfeit passport and other official documents.
    • One must note that the ISPS Code and SOLAS apply to ships greater than 500 GT, engaged on international voyages. However, Governments have to make all vessels and port facilities secure whether they used by foreign going ships or not.
